questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents to the pediatric clinic for a routine check-up. His height and development are within 50th percentile. What is the most appropriate expected weight for the child?

A 3-month-old infant presents for a well-baby check-up. During previous visits, the head circumference was below the normal range His birth head circumference was 33 cm. What is the expected head circumference for the child?
A newborn presented with chest retractions, dyspnea, and lethargy. The pediatrician diagnosed the baby with respiratory distress syndrome. This occurs due to the deficiency of:
Which of the following is the best sign to indicate adequate growth in an infant with a birth weight of 2.8 kg?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in length of 25 centimeters in the first year

options.label: B
options.text: Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year

options.label: C
options.text: Anterior fontanel closure by 6 months of age

options.label: D
options.text: Weight under 75th percentile and height under 25th percentile

questions.correct_answer: A. Increase in length of 25 centimeters in the first year
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Increase in length of 25 centimeters in the first year

questions.text: A child is brought to the hospital with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor. The radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
A 3-month-old baby comes with complaints of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
An infant presents with hepatosplenomegaly and thrombocytopenia. Neuroimaging with CT shows periventricular calcifications. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 3-week-old infant presents with a cough and sore throat. The mother reports that the infant develops a paroxysm of cough followed by apnea. The total leucocyte count is >50,000 cells/μL. Which of the following drugs will you prescribe for this patient?
A 1-day-old neonate has not passed urine since birth. What is the next step in management?
A baby presented with abdominal pain. On examination, a mass is palpated in the right lumbar region. A barium enema is done, and the image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 10-month-old infant was brought with complaints of jerking movement of limbs toward the body. On examination, there is a regression of developmental milestones. Electroencephalogram shows hypsarrhythmia. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition?
A newborn baby born through normal vaginal delivery. The vitals were stable and delayed cord clamping was done. Identify two drawbacks of delayed cord clamping during delivery?

A child presented with a history of loose stools with an increase in frequency for 4 days. On examination, he is drowsy, unable to feed, and skin on pinching goes back very slowly. According to the Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI), this child will be classified as having:
A 10-year-old child presents with edema and anasarca. A diagnosis of minimal change disease is made. Which of the following is true about this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Light microscopy shows effacement of podocytes

questions.text: A child with infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis has multiple episodes of nonbilious vomiting. Which of the following metabolic abnormality is likely to be seen in this condition?
A 3-month-old baby is brought with intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis and hydrocephalus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
At what pressure, pop valve is released in bag and mask ventilation?
Maximum lymphoid growth is seen at what age?
A 1-month-old baby came with complaints of projectile vomiting with olive shape mass. X-ray abdomen was done. What is the diagnosis?
Failure to thrive baby with skin lesions improved on gluten free diet. Which of the following disease is associated with the condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Celiac disease - TTG will be positive

questions.correct_answer: A. Celiac disease - TTG will be positive
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Celiac disease - TTG will be positive

questions.text: A newborn baby born with a congenital defect. Identify the defect shown in the image:
A mother delivers a 2.5 kg baby with normal vaginal delivery in a rural area. Which of the following is an incorrect statement?

options.label: B
options.text: Bathe the baby with warm water immediately

questions.correct_answer: B. Bathe the baby with warm water immediately
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Bathe the baby with warm water immediately

questions.text: In the ice lined refrigerator’s lowest compartment, which vaccine is kept?

Which of the following children are considered at-risk babies? Baby with a birth weight of 2.5 kg Baby on artificial feeds Baby of working mother/single parent Baby with weight <85% of expected weight Birth order of 3 or more

A male child presented with arthralgia and abdominal pain. On examination, there was palpable purpura over the lower limbs. There is past history of upper respiratory tract infection prior to the onset of presenting symptoms. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition?

A young child with congenital hydrocephalus was treated with a successful ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt. Four months’ postsurgical repair, the child presented with fever, nuchal rigidity and irritability. You suspect meningitis. What is the next best step?

options.label: B
options.text: Check shunt patency by nuclear study

options.label: C
options.text: Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap

options.label: D
options.text: Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture

questions.correct_answer: C. Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap

questions.text: In fetal circulation, which vessel carries deoxygenated blood back to the placenta?

A 4-year-old child came with complaints of bowing of legs and widening of wrist. On further examination, the child appears to have low serum calcium with the image shown as follows. Choose the best answer:
What are the vitamin K dependent clotting factors?
A 5-year-old baby came with suspected case of IEM. During the urine workup, the junior resident on duty found that there was darkening of urine on standing. What is the best possible diagnosis?
A 10-month-old baby presented with perioral rash/perivaginal rash with history of delayed wound healing. Which is the most common nutrient deficiency in this case?
Which of the following is not included in NADAS criteria?
A child copies a cross, tells rhymes and goes to the toilet on her own. What is her age?
Correct statement about breast milk jaundice is:

options.label: D
options.text: Bilirubin level is more than 10 mg/dL at 3-4 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following holds true for “some dehydration” in a child? Thirst: increased Mental state: lethargic Skin pinch: delayed Sunken eyes: present
What is the rate of increase in head circumference in the first 3 months of life?
Downes’ score includes which all of the following? Respiratory rate Cyanosis Feeding Retractions
INSURE technique is used in:

Which of the following are CORRECT regarding febrile seizure? Simple febrile seizures are generalized tonic and clonic seizures not lasting more than 15 minutes, occurring in children with fever of 38 degrees between 6 months to 5 years and only once in 24 hours Chance of recurrence after one episode of febrile seizure is 54% Long term anticonvulsants are not indicated in simple febrile seizures CT is indicated in patients in whom there is high risk of structural abnormalities, metabolic disturbances within the age of 3 years
The best indicator of some dehydration in SAM is:
Out of the following, which clinical feature is not seen in Down syndrome?
A 9-month-child presents with fever and cough. On examination there are no chest retractions and RR is 46 bpm. What will be the diagnosis and management?

options.label: A
options.text: No pneumonia is diagnosed symptomatic treatment will be given patient and will be sent home with warning signs

options.label: C
options.text: Mild pneumonia send with oral antibiotics

questions.correct_answer: A. No pneumonia is diagnosed symptomatic treatment will be given patient and will be sent home with warning signs
questions.explanation: Ans. A) No pneumonia is diagnosed symptomatic treatment will be given patient and will be sent home with warning signs

questions.text: Which can be used as an alternative to mother’s milk in a low birth weight (LBW) baby?
Which of the following is the most effective indicator of successful ventilatory effort in neonatal resuscitation?

Regarding urinary tract infection (UTI) in children, which of the following is true? Most common cause of UTI is streptococcus pneumoniae. Bowel, bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrence Cotrimoxazole is not given Micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU) is done in children with recurrence of UTI

Which of the following cyanotic heart disease causes increased pulmonary blood flow? Ebstein anomaly Tetralogy of Fallot Transposition of the great arteries (TGA) Total anomalous pulmonary venous communication (TAPVC)

An 11-year-old boy was brought to the outpatient clinic with intentional tremors, and poor scholastic performance. His sister has similar complaints. On examination, hepatomegaly is seen. The eye findings are shown in the following image. What is the probable diagnosis?

Which of the following statements is true regarding the tape shown in the image? It is called Shelter’s tape. It is used to assess severe acute malnutrition. Reading of 13.5–14.5 cm is considered undernourished. It is mainly useful for frontline field workers.
Which of the following are components of kangaroo mother care?

options.label: A
options.text: Early discharge, skin to skin contact, prevent infection

options.label: B
options.text: Early discharge, skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding

options.label: C
options.text: Skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, prevent infection

options.label: D
options.text: Early discharge, exclusive breastfeeding and prevent infection

questions.correct_answer: B. Early discharge, skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Early discharge, skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding

questions.text: Match the following developmental milestones:
At what age does a child attain half-height of the adult height?

Cerebral palsy is a group of motor disorders resulting from non-progressive brain damage, and various types exist based on the nature and distribution of motor impairments. Among the different types, which form constitutes the most common presentation of cerebral palsy in children?

A 3-year-old child is brought to the pediatric dentist for a routine examination. The parents express concerns about the child's oral health. How many teeth should typically be present in the oral cavity of a 3-year-old:

A 14-year-old patient with hepatomegaly, neurological symptoms, change in handwriting, decrease school performance and intention tremors undergoes genetic testing for confirmation of suspected genetic disease. To identify the specific gene mutation associated with this autosomal recessive disorder, which of the following genes should be analyzed?

During a routine developmental assessment, a pediatrician observes a 3-year-old child demonstrating emerging fine motor skills. The child is asked to draw a circle as part of the evaluation. At which age milestone is it typically expected for a child to successfully draw a circle?

In the neonatal intensive care unit, a premature infant is born with a birth weight of 850 grams. To categorize the degree of prematurity and guide appropriate medical interventions, the healthcare team refers to the extremely low birth weight (ELBW) cutoff. What is the generally accepted ELBW cutoff?

options.label: A
options.text: Less than 500 grams; facilitating prompt respiratory support

options.label: B
options.text: Less than 750 grams; guiding nutritional interventions

options.label: C
options.text: Less than 1,000 grams; aiding in temperature regulation strategies

options.label: D
options.text: Less than 1,500 grams; indicating the need for developmental follow-up

questions.correct_answer: C. Less than 1,000 grams; aiding in temperature regulation strategies
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Less than 1,000 grams; aiding in temperature regulation strategies

questions.text: In a pediatric hepatology clinic, a 3-month-old infant is presented with jaundice, pale stools, and dark urine. The pediatrician suspects conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and initiates further investigations. What underlying conditions or disorders should be considered in the differential diagnosis, as they are commonly associated with elevated conjugated bilirubin levels?

In a neonatal intensive care unit, a nurse observes a newborn as part of routine assessments and notices certain characteristics related to the eyes. To better understand the normal features of a newborn's pupils and their implications, the nurse initiates a discussion with colleagues. What is the distinctive characteristics of a newborn's pupils?

In a neonatal intensive care unit, a premature infant is being evaluated for suspected sepsis, and the healthcare team is considering laboratory markers to aid in diagnosis. Which specific acute phase reactant serves as a valuable marker in the acute-phase response to infection in neonates :

A full-term newborn presents with cleft palate, hypocalcemia-induced seizures, and congenital heart disease (interrupted aortic arch). On examination, the baby has micrognathia and low-set ears. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to multiple café-au-lait macules, axillary freckling, and an optic glioma. His father also has similar skin lesions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A term baby is born with microcephaly, polydactyly, cleft lip/palate, and neonatal respiratory distress due to pulmonary hypoplasia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
The causative agent of the condition shown in the following image is associated with which of the following disorders?
A 5-year-old boy presents with supravalvular aortic stenosis, hypercalcemia, and an overly friendly personality. He has elfin facies with wide mouth and full lips. What is the most likely syndrome?
Nada’s Minor Criteria include: Systolic murmur Grade 3 Diastolic murmur Abnormal second heart sound Abnormal BP
A term neonate weighing 3 kg is admitted to the NICU. What is the fluid requirement on Day 1 of life?
A newborn at 1 minute has a heart rate of 120/min, irregular respiration, some flexion, grimaces to stimulation, and pink body with blue extremities. What is the APGAR score?
A 4-year-old child has a height of 100 cm. What is the expected height at 12 years?
A 15 kg child requires how much maintenance fluid per day according to the Holliday-Segar formula?

In a pediatric clinic, a concerned parent brings in their newborn for a thorough examination due to observed physical features. During the examination of your newborn, distinct features such as an anti-Mongoloid slant of the eyes, pulmonary stenosis, and undescended testes were observed. These findings can be indicative of a specific syndrome. Can you identify the syndrome associated with these characteristics

In a developmental pediatrics clinic, parents express curiosity about their child's milestones, particularly regarding the acquisition of fine motor skills such as tying shoelaces. At what age can a child be expected to master the skill of tying shoelaces independently?
A 2-year-old boy presents with a high-pitched cat-like cry, microcephaly, and intellectual disability. Genetic testing shows a deletion on chromosome. What is the chromosome & diagnosis?
A 4-year-old patient came with decreased weight for height <–3 SD with MUAC <11.5 cm with anasarca and abdominal distension. What is the best interpretation?

options.label: A
options.text: Marasmus is due to deficiency of calories + hypoalbuminemia + proteins

options.label: B
options.text: Kwashiorkor is due to deficiency of proteins

options.label: C
options.text: Marasmus is due to deficiency of calories + proteins

options.label: D
options.text: Marasmus is due to deficiency of calories only

questions.correct_answer: B. Kwashiorkor is due to deficiency of proteins
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Kwashiorkor is due to deficiency of proteins

questions.text: During an epidemic, an 8-month-old baby came for its routine measles vaccination, mother wants to enquire about the next dose of measles vaccination. What should the nurse tell the mother?
A child presents with syndactyly, broad thumbs, intellectual disability, and a deletion on chromosome 16p13. What is the likely diagnosis?
